participants.participant: Jan H.M. Hommen, chairman Executive Board
Koos J.V. Timmermans, member Executive Board and Chief Risk Officer
Jan H.M. Hommen, Chairman Executive Board

plist.p: Good morning. Welcome to ING's First Quarter 2009 Conference Call. Before handing this conference call over to Jan Hommen, Chief Executive Officer of ING Group; Patrick Flynn, Chief Financial Officer; and Koos Timmermans, Chief Risk Officer; let me first say that any forward-looking statements in today's comments are subject to a number of variables including interest rates, foreign exchange rates, inflation rates, movements in securities markets including equity markets and underlying economic conditions and changes. The realization of forward-looking statements could be materially altered by unexpected movements in any or all of these and other variables.
Good morning Jan, Patrick and Koos. Jan, over to you.

Thank you very much. Welcome everyone. I am here with Koos Timmermans, our Chief Risk Officer; Patrick Flynn, our new CFO; who joined us at the end of April. And I am also here with Tom McInerney, Head of U.S. Insurance activities, America Insurance activities, and Dick Harryvan, who runs our ING Direct business.
Let me start with the first slides and then let me take you through the presentation and then Koos will later pick up from me and explain the numbers in more detail.

First, I would like to take you through the progress we are making on the cost containment on the de-risking and the de-leveraging initiatives that we have announced in January. And then I'll walk you through some of the changes in the corporate governance structure which are intended to increase our focus on the business and will bring us really – and let us work back to our basics.

And then I will take a look at the highlights for Q1 where the loss narrowed substantially from Q4 to 305 million on an underlying basis. All business lines improved compare to Q4 and all three bank business lines reported a profit in Q1 despite higher risk costs. Insurance continued to post losses as a result of volatile markets that we still saw in the first quarter of 2009.

I move to slide three. You will remember the change program that we introduced in January. And I promised that we would update you every quarter on the progress we are making. The first priority is to reduce costs, to reduce risk and de-leverage to strengthen ING as we navigate through the ongoing crisis. And we have made significant progress on those fronts, as you will see in the coming slides.

The second phase that I outlined at that time, at the Investor Conference Day on April 9, was to focus on fewer businesses as we seek to simplify the Group and to focus on markets where we have leadership positions. We have said we plan to exit 10 to 15 businesses in this process; however divestments will be pursued prudently as market conditions permit.

We will have no fire sales and this is not an easy market to sale our businesses in. In the mean time under the phase three, we are strengthening the organization to reinforce the accountability, simplify the governance and reduce complexity, and today we have announced the change to the governance structure of the Group, that's an important step in realizing these goals.

Slide number four, you see our cost reductions and they are really tracking so that we can realize a billion or probably even more by the end of this year. Operating expenses in Q1 were reduced by 231 million, excluding foreign exchange. And then total operating expense were down 3.5% compared to Q1 last year at 13.3% compared to Q4 despite higher impairments on real estate development projects and higher deposits insurance premiums that we had to pay, and despite also higher acquisitions of CitiStreet and Interhyp that we did last year.

Slide number five is showing the people reduction we have accomplished so far. We are ahead of our plan in reducing our workforce. Of the 7,000 job cuts that we announced, 5,380 have been completed by the end of Q1. These are cuts that come on top of the head count reduction that we already announced earlier from the merger of the Postbank and ING Bank in the Netherlands. That project led to a reduction of 578 full-time equivalents in Q1. There is also a significant reduction of third-party staff in the first quarter as well.

Now let's move to slide number six. The de-risking measures are on track. We are making good progress. Direct equity exposure has been reduced from over 13 billion a year ago to just 5 billion now. Of that total, half represents strategic stakes at the banking business, including Kookmin Bank and Bank of Beijing, where the market values have increased in Q1.

The equity exposure of the insurance business is down to 2.6 billion. We have also taken important steps to reduce the portfolio of asset-backed securities that we hold available for sale in order to reduce the volatility in our IFRS equity going forwards. And most importantly, of course, was the Alt-A transaction with the Dutch state, which led to a deconsolidation of 80% of our Alt-A portfolio.

We also reclassified assets, largely asset-based securities, in January, which reduced the available-for-sale portfolio by about 13 billion. This brought portfolio of asset-backed securities held available for sale to 35 billion from 72 billion at year-end.

We have taken steps to further tighten the loan underwriting given the worsening economic climate, and in the U.S., we are de-risking and re-pricing our variable annuity products. In Japan, we have decided to stop selling SPVAs, which will be phased out by the end of July. But we will continue to sell our COLI, our corporate-owned life insurance activities in Japan. And then we have a number of other measures reducing exposure to financial institutions, reducing the investment portfolio at ING Direct over time, and shifting to more own-originated assets, and measures to mitigate the risk-weighted asset growth. And Koos will you give more detail when he explains the details a little bit later.

On slide number seven, you see the balance sheet reductions are progressing ahead of schedule. Our plan was to reduce 10% of our balance sheet by the end of Q3 last year, and we have already reduced and achieved a reduction of 7% bringing the total assets for the bank now below the one trillion level.

The next slide is showing the changes we are making to the governance structure. We have decided to create separate management boards for Bank and Insurance. The Group Executive Board will consist of three members, myself, Koos and Patrick. And three of us will also serve as the CEO, CRO and CFO of the Banking and the Insurance Boards.

Within the Banking Boards, the business line responsibilities will remain the same: Eli Leenaars for Retail, Dick Harryvan for ING Direct, and Eric Boyer for the Commercial Bank. In Insurance, Hans van der Noordaa will take over responsibility for Europe in addition to his current responsibilities for Asia, and Jacques de Vaucleroy will become the head of our New Global Asset Management business line, while Tom McInerney will maintain responsibility for the Americas.

We have a few benefits related to the structure. It creates a single management team for each business with clear accountability – one bank, one management team and one balance sheet – and it achieves this result, creating an additional layer of managements.

The CEO, the CFO and the CRO will continue to maintain the overview of the Group as a whole and will participate on all three boards. But most importantly, it is freeing up the business people and the board to really focus more their time on the business activities. So this is an important step for us in our back to basics program.

Slide number nine, it's a slide that you have seen before, I will be brief. We are focusing on fewer businesses with a simplified business model where we are going closer to the customer with fewer and simple products with more efficient processes.

Let's look at the Q1 results now. The market environment in Q1 remained quite challenging. As you can see on slide number 10, where we have a number of indicators that project the economic environment we had in Q1. We see that economic growth is slowing. The stock markets continue to decline. They have seen a rebound in April and May. Interest rates are lower and credit spreads have remained at elevated levels.

Slide number 11, you see the financial results and despite these challenging environments, the loss that we reported narrowed substantially compared to Q4. At the bottom of the slide you see the underlying net loss narrowed from 3.7 billion in Q4 to 305 million in Q1.

The total market impact on results declined from 5 billion negative in Q4 to 1.7 billion negative, still a substantial amount that are stemming from impairments, negative revaluation on assets, and other market impacts, although substantially less than it was before. And at the same time, you see that our loan loss provisions are increasing at the banking business as the financial crisis is now moving to the real economy.

Slide number 12, you see the buildup of the results in both the bank and the insurance business. The bank had a profit of just under 700 million, despite loan losses of 772 million loan loss provisions and insurance was impacted by the adverse market conditions particularly as it related to DAC.

On slide number 13, you see that our commercial performance continued to be resilient, there we had net client production of 11.2 billion and growth was mainly by strong inflow of savings of the ING Direct notably in the U.S. and Germany. And retail banking had a strong inflow, particularly in Belgium. Our mortgage and our lending business has slowed in the current economic environment, although we continue to show growth in our lending, be it at a very modest rate.

Also banking declined which is reflecting lower corporate bank balances and a small decline in lending. And insurance saw small outflows in the America and in Europe, while at the same time they saw an increase in the balances in Asia/Pacific.

Looking at our capital on slide 14. You see that our ratio is continued to be in target. Core Tier 1 improved to 7.5 and Tier 1 improved to 9.7%. Debt equity for insurance increased to 9.6, but remains within the limits of 15% and the debt equity at the Group was unchanged at 13.5%.
And let me now hand over to Koos who will give you more details on our financials.

Okay. Turning to the Bank and now we're on page 15. Jan explained the measures taken reduce risk and cost and if you look at that the Group overall had a net loss of 793 million, the Bank returned to profit. Market conditions there remained challenging, but actually if you look at it, income recovered, almost to the level of first quarter of '08, lower impairments improved interest results and strong financial market results. If you look at cost cutting on the banking side is on track. It's down almost 3% versus Q1 '08 and down 12% from Q4.

Loan loss provisions is on the rise given the economic slowdown, 108 basis point of credit risk-weighted assets. The improvement in underlying results can be more clearly seen on slide 16. And on slide 16, we normally focus more Q1 versus Q1, but the environment has changed so dramatically that it's better to focus for this time on Q4.

Three important points on this slide; and that is first if you look at third line from the bottom, the underlying net result recovered from losses over 1 billion to a profit of 519 million. And the most important drivers of that are the fifth line from the top and that is the significant reduction of impairments versus Q4 notably in the Alt-A after the transaction with the Dutch State.

And in the middle, you see the increase in the loan loss provisions to 772 million where you actually see that the financial crisis is more moving to the real economy. And within the Bank, the improvement overall has been driven by the Wholesale Bank and that is what we can see on slide 17.

And on slide 17, you see all three business lines showing an upward trend led by the Wholesale Banking part. And on the right hand side, Wholesale strong improvement to 506 million, driven by Financial Markets. Actually in Financial Markets, it is predominantly the customer driven business rather than the proprietary where we made this money and there is been an increased Capital Markets, Debt Capital Markets activity.
If you look at Retail Banking side, it's up versus quarter Q4. And that's in part an improvement on operating expenses, but still significantly down as compared to a year earlier.

Margin pressure on savings in the Netherlands due to competition plays a big role. Loan loss provisioning up and that is mainly in the SME section. We look in the middle, ING Direct, a strong improvement from Q4. There where we had the significant impairments on the Alt-A and operating expenses down almost 10%.

Commercial activity in ING Direct was also strong in Q1. Let's look at slide 18. If you look at slide 18, we see the customer inflows overall. On the Bank, they improved to 11.3 billion net inflow of savings in Q1 and that reversed the trend of outflow from Q4.

The increase was led by ING Direct plus 11 billion mainly in the U.S. and Germany. And if you look at the Netherlands, I mean we have the strong competition for savings. I mean competitors, they are paying over interbank rate to get in savings and we have to maintain discipline in pricing and that's why the growth is more in ING Direct than in the other parts.

If you look at margins, and then we're on the next page, page 19, interest margins, they remained stable at the 117 rate. It's a slight flattening of interest margins due to the savings competition in the Netherlands. If you look at ING Direct, it's up versus Q4 as central bank, they cut their interest rates and we followed particularly in the U.S.

Eurozone countries, we are not able to follow rates down as much and that is due to the competition there. We move to the loan losses. Look at the net addition of loan losses, the 108 basis points, it's on the rise. There is a lagging impact. I mean the crisis is now from financial more moving to the real economy. And the increase is driven by SME lending in retail. And Deterioration of the U.S. housing market in ING Direct and then we have Real Estate Finance, Structured Finance in the Wholesale.

If we turn to the insurance business, so we are at slide 21, there again you see an improvement versus Q4. However, the insurance company is still loss-making, 824 million, that's due to impairments, revaluations and the DAC unlocking in the U.S.
VMB is down by about a half and that is due to lower sales of unit-linked and it's also it's an active decision in the sense that we want to re-price and de-risk our VAs in U.S. and Japan.

So, to help to understand the movement behind those results, let's go to page 22. On page 22, let's focus again on the comparison with Q4. Towards the top, you see that the impairments, they continue to be painful but substantially less than in Q4. In the middle, you see that the DAC unlocking is the other significant number there, mainly in the U.S. And if you look at other markets impacts and that is the minus 488 which you see, these come from the insurance primarily from a few factors. One is we have our so-called separate account shortfall in the Netherlands. So, that's the group pension business, another 164 million and we have 195 million of Japan hedging and accounting volatility there. So, those are the biggest contributors to the other factor.

If we move to page 23, insurance, what you see in the middle is a widening loss in the insurance. Americas minus 510 million. That is for 550 explained by the DAC unlocking. Credit losses improved versus Q4. If you look at operating expenses, they are at minus 20% excluding FX and the acquisition of CitiStreet.

We move to the left. There you see euro, loss narrow to 75 million. We have the several account shortfalls in the Netherlands and we have the revaluations of real estate. So, those are the negative factors. Positive however is the operating expenses minus 17% from Q4. We move to the right-hand side, Asia. There is a loss driven by the hedge volatility in Japan. Expenses are down by 20%.

Now, let's go back to the DAC unlocking on slide 24. First, we look at the equity-related DAC unlocking. I mean the rule of thumb is that the S&P 500 minus 10% from the 225 assumption per quarter, means 100 million DAC.

On Q1, we had the S&P at minus 11% and the DAC unlocking was about half, rule of thumb due to equity hedges. So, this quarter, more significant impact came from the other DAC unlocking and that is on page 25.

If we look at page 25, the other DAC. It reflects mainly changes in the value of the guaranteed benefit costs and these are driven by interest rates, equity volatility and guarantees moving into the money.

In Q1, we see guarantees moving further into the money and that contributed most of the impact in Q1. If we look at the commercial activity and that is on page 26. On page 26, we see the sales – they continued to decline. There is less demand for investment linked products in Q1, notably the decline in VA sales in the U.S. and in Japan and we de-risked and re-priced products. So partially it's active, but partially it is also a market demand for investment product which is lower. VNB, had declined 57% due to lower sales, higher hedging cost and particularly again in the VAs and in U.S. and Japan.

If we move to page 27, as we announced in April, we are taking measures to reduce the risk in our VA business and going forward, we will reposition the business to focus on lower risk roll-over products.

And new products are being developed for launch in 2010 which will use only index funds, so that reduces your tracking error and it will offer a reduced guarantee and will pay lower commissions over the life of the product instead of large up front commissions and in the meantime we are also taking steps to reduce risk in the in-force book and the current products and for the in-force, we are temporarily fetching hedging fee income and we have fully hedged the equity funds.

Index funds, they have increased to 25% of the mix from 9% so that means less tracking our own debt side and for the current products, adjustments were made to the products in January and again in May. And those adjustments, they have to do with the withdrawal benefit rollup that was reduced to 6%, rider changes have been increased, commissions they have been reduced and interest rate hedging has been put in place and for income benefit products the payout interest rates were reduced to 1%.

We now move to the Risk section and on the Risk section, again overall and that's on page 28, we see an improvement versus Q4, however the insurance company is still loss making. Impairments we'll discuss revaluations and DAC unlocking in the U.S.

I'm sorry – let me move from that basically to page 29, and then let's first zoom in and focus on the asset class, the ABSs. First, on page 29, what you see is, with the ABS, is you see a significant downward move from 72 billion to 39 billion. First, that has to do with the fact that we have changed our Alt-A portfolio and we now have a state receivable. So that's a real risk transfer, but secondly what we also did is we did reclassifications. So in essence we had reclassified part of our ABS portfolio to the loans and receivables. So that means we are holding it to maturity and it means like we have less of the effects of changing market prices on our IFRS equity.

The third element is, in general, you could say all asset classes are basically down in terms of actual exposure except for U.S. agency RMBSs -- that is something which we had increased over the quarter. One of the things to note there is if I look at the CDOs we excluded synthetic CDOs and not because they have disappeared, but they have basically – they are moved to mark-to-market. And actually if you look at the fair value loss in Q1 on this, that was 39 million, so a small amount.
We did have maturing bonds in the portfolio, 2 billion over the Q1, and the negative revaluations, the marks there were lower than in the previous quarters.

If we then move to the Alt-A portfolio, in the Alt-A portfolio, you see an IFRS pre-tax impairment at the bottom-line of 178 million. In essence, you also see no cash losses still on the bonds and that is the Alt-A RMBS, they have not missed a coupon or re-payment, as the losses they are still allocated to the junior tranches.

At the same time, future estimated credit losses on the newly impaired RMBSs there will be, you know that is still an amount triggering a 128 million impairment and on top of that we have to re-impair securities because that is something which is required with IFRS and marks on Alt-A going down for 50 million and that gives us the total of the 178 million.

Total credit losses, which we would have impaired if we were on US GAAP, would have been 88 million. So that is only the Alt-A portfolio if we move to the direct equity exposure on direct equity the insurance equity portfolio, 2.6 billion and we have out of the money put options for that portfolio and that is a bit more the put options than the cash value of this portfolio, but it also serves a bit as a proxy hedge on our private equity portfolio.
Then next to that we have our hedge position on the fee income and that is on the DAC related part that should be seen separately from the cash equity hedges, which we have on the insurance side.
If I move to the bank, on the banking side what we have seen is a slight increase and that has to do with the value of the stake of Bank of Beijing that has moved up.

Then let's move to the balance sheet reduction. If you look at balance sheet reduction, I mean that is on slide 32, there is actually quite a few things to be noted there. On the first is overall you see that your total assets is going down and that is what you see moving to the 979 million – billion, then that is to do with basically predominantly the non – lending assets. So that is the first movement what you see.

The second move what you see is that the component, which does not revalue via the revaluation reserve, has gone up because that is the part loans and advances, the 617 billion. Now is that all because we made more loans, no there is the part in there, which is the Alt-A facility and there is the part in there which is the reclassification.

So that means we make the balance sheet less vulnerable to revaluation changes, but at the same time if you look at it more from a liquidity perspective and a loan-to-deposit perspective then I would focus on the lending section, the 580 billion which brings me to page 33. And on page 33, you actually see the funding mix and the loan-to-deposit ratio. What you see there is in essence that the funding mix, I mean not a lot of things have changed there, the loan-to-deposit ratio slightly improved to 109.

And what we are doing there is we are basically looking at the funding mix of the deposits of 531 billion and we compare it to a 580 billion loan portfolio. If we move from that to an insight in the negative revaluations for our portfolio on page 34, what you see there is the total movement in the negative revaluations, 11.8 billion negative. The biggest mark comes from the ABSs, minus 7.1 billion. And what we also note there is if you look at the more contractual average maturity of these, by no change in credit spread or no change in interest rate, you would have a pool to bar effect on this by around 2 billion per year. But, okay, that is the assumption then, no changes in interest rate, no changes on credit spreads.

If we move to page 35, let's look at the asset leverage of the bank. What you see there is the following: we see the shareholders' equity of the bank and we made an adjustment. The adjustment which we made is we said, well, if we look at the debt securities on the banking balance sheet, and if we would give them the same treatment, so add it to shareholders' equity, where on the asset side, we take the negative marks on the investments out. If we do that like-for-like, so asset side is negative for reval reserve, but on the liability side, it's positive, then you end up with a pro-forma shareholders' equity of 33. And if you compare that to a total balance sheet size, then you end up on an asset leverage of 30.

Simple thing, I am still not a fan of the simple cap of the asset leverage because there are quite some disadvantages. One is comparisons are difficult. I mean, and we talk about US GAAP and the allowance there for derivatives netting. Second is you don't take well all the off balance sheet exposures into consideration in this measure. Nevertheless, we wanted to share this leverage with you.

If we now move from this to the loan portfolio, then what you see is the originated loans, the NPLs, they remain relatively stable. Let's first look at the mortgages. Overall, on the mortgage side, non-performing loans, you only see a marginal deterioration over the whole portfolio. I think the biggest component what you see is the United States. And there you see that the NPLs, they have moved up by 1%. It is still an out-performance versus the U.S. industry if you compare it with the prime floaters. Nevertheless, that is where you have seen an uptick.

If I look at the commercial loans, we have 220 billion of commercial loans and that is basically corporate, mid-corporate SME. It does exclude counter-party and government. If you look at that element then you see some upticks in general and that is especially on the structured finance side, but you also see it on the real estate finance side.

If we then zoom in on the loan loss provision, and that is on page 27. On page 27, you see the net additions there and actually what you see is it's a broad, a broader deterioration and it is reflecting the economics and it's especially more in the structured finance U.S. mortgages private banking and the Netherlands business lending. So, those are the biggest contributors to the loan losses.

If we then move to the risk-weighted assets, we look at risk-weighted assets, one thing is we did see an impact of rating migration over the quarter. Nevertheless, overall, our risk-weighted assets declined. So, there has been quite some balancing effect there.

The first thing is we had a positive risk-weighted asset migration, a positive, I mean it's going up and that is because of securitization of U.S. mortgages and structured finance. So, that increased our risk-weighted assets. Then we had our facility with the state and that decreased our risk-weighted assets. Then we had our balance sheet reductions, what Jan was also talking about, that has a negative effect on risk-weighted assets. And then we had foreign exchange which has a positive one. Overall, over the quarter, it has been a decline in risk-weighted assets on our side.

Now, I think if we look back a bit at what happened over the – in the current crisis, if you look at 2008, in 2008 we have seen a lot of movements in the financial markets. And if you look at those movements in the financial markets, I don't need to remind the equity markets and the real estates going down and those credit spreads going up and house prices going down. It had for us – it had its major effect in '08 on both the impairments and the revaluations through the P&L and it also had its effect on the revaluations in debt securities.

Overall, as what you witness in our results, you see that the market effects are getting a bit lower right now, that we are now more turning towards the real economy and that is why we looked more specifically at our loan book and we made a sort of a scenario where we said like where can risk cost, or how could it move? And what we did is the following: I mean, we made a sort of a scenario there and we said like let us assume that markets, unemployment, property prices and levels of default are going to deteriorate as of the first of January this year.

And so the example here is unemployment as of the first of January this year in Europe is going up by 5%. Property prices as compared to the first of January in Europe going down. Also we look at then we've translated this into levels of default. So we said like, well, we normally measure default levels over '08 and that is what we model. And then we said like, well, if you have these unemployment and property prices moving, what will be the effects on defaults? Then what we did is, we said like, well we take a two-year scenario. So we'll look at this for two years at the loan books and then we are going to see, like, well what would be the additions in loan loss provisioning, what we would model, if such a scenario happens.

And by the way, I only gave you three inputs. So the unemployment properties and corporate PDs, but of course we also looked at elements like emerging markets, counterparty risks, so we tested the whole lot of what goes via accrual.

What happens, actually, is the following: If these inputs, if that happens, so that is the scenario, then what you see is basically an average, you see your total losses moving to 154 basis points of average credit risk-weighted assets in 2010.

So what did we do? We projected two years of losses, we divided it by the average credit risk-weighted assets and then we divided it by two so that you have a comparable annual number. So again a few things to be said about this. This is not, sort of, the expectation which I have, but this is if the market would move those factors which you see on the left hand side, would be the deterioration as from the 1st of January then over two years' time, this is what I would expect to happen on the loan losses.

So what does it say? So again, it's not my expectation, it's the sensitivity and again, what do you have to do with this? You have to relate this to your anticipated commercial results because that would inevitably be your first buffer to, sort of, catch up those losses. So this is where I want to leave it with regards to the stress test on our loan portfolio and then I hand back to you, Jan.
Thank you, Koos. I would say that this is sufficient for the presentation at this point in time. Let's see what type of questions that you have and we will try to answer your questions.
. The first question comes from Marc Thiele from UBS. Please go ahead with your question.

Good morning. I have three questions. The first thing is, can you help us a bit regarding your equity market exposure? Can you give us a bit of explanation how these 5 billion will move in line with the main indices? And does the color structure provide you to participate in the upside, quarter to date? And will this result in any hedging losses that we need to think about in terms of the P&L?

The second question is regarding the separate account provisions in the Netherlands, the 164. Is there a certain interest rate level or equity market level that we need to think about when these things could actually reverse into the other direction? Or is there risk that there could be further provisioning, and can you give us a sort of guideline what sort of levels we should be thinking of on a macro economic basis?

My third question is more of a sense check. Looking at your page 12, earnings, if we look at the bank and include the loan loss provisions, it produced 1.1 billion in the first quarter. If we then look at the insurance business, the 3 to 400 million, let's say the Group produces 1.4 to 1.5 billion in terms of the run rate, but you are indicating there will be further cost reductions, but equally there will be more de-risking in terms of the bank's balance sheet. Do we need to think of additional factors impacting the earnings outlook going forward or would you disagree, looking at 1.6 to 1.7 billion as a quarterly underlying pre-tax run rate?
Okay. Thanks, Marc. Koos, will you take the first?

Yeah. Maybe I would like to split it in two things. First is, we look at the equity cash part, then we look at fee income, and then we look at specifically DAC. If you look at the equity cash part, on the banking side, what I explained, it's basically naked, because those are stakes and those are – basically it's Kookmin and it's the Bank of Beijing. And you know we would not hedge that, and there is – if markets move up, I mean, clearly you have a benefit there.

If I look at the equity cash side on the insurance, then you can say it's hedged. What we do is we hedge it with puts, but we also hedge it with collars to finance some of the puts. So to give you the precise sensitivity is a difficult one, because it's non-linear. I mean in the end. And there is one other factor which plays a role, that if you look at our portfolio, the cash side is non-financials and we hedge it with indexes, and in indexes are the financial as well. So, that means that there is not a precise tracking between the two. So, it's very difficult to give you precise sensitivity in one benchmark on the equity hedges.

If we move to the U.S. businesses, in the U.S. businesses, there is a few factors playing a role. There is a hedging of a benefit and the equity component, and there is a hedging of the fee income, and on the fee income, from time-to-time, we put hedges in place, and we do have hedges in place right now. Most of them at this moment are more linear. So futures, and over time, we are replacing that a bit more by non-linear transaction as well. So, doing a bit more puts. But then what you do is you trade in upside for basically paying a fix fee. And I don't know Tom if there is anything you want to share on this. Okay. So that's it on the equity side.
Yes, and the separate accounts?

If you look at the separate account. I mean the shortfall of the separate account over this quarter, what you've seen is, well, liabilities moving -- basically that was the negative part. And if you see like what did we make on it, I mean we compensated it partially with swaps. We compensated it partially with equity derivatives. And then we have swaptions as well. And what you've seen is implied volatilities are not moving up. So, you have a bit of a negative mark on the swaption side as well. So, overall that creates your account shortfall which we have on this portfolio. It's a difficult one to hedge perfectly well. So, equity prices played a role, implied volatility as well as interest rates.

Okay. Your final question dealt with the results going forward. That's always a tricky subject because our policy is not to comment on forward-looking numbers here. Let me help you a little bit though. The first quarter normally is a bit better than the – let's say the first two quarter are normally a bit better than the quarters in the second half. So I – that's the only guidance I can give you. I think at this moment I want to prefer not to any further.

Yes, I didn't expect it to give us a precise number just thinking was there anything in addition that we need to think about and has that you think has influenced to result significantly and would there be any other future items other than the cost reductions and de-risking play into the numbers that we need to think of?

No, I would say no, except to say that our results in financial markets this quarter of course were very, very solid. And it all depends on how the trading markets will develop in the future whether we can maintain them. Other than that I would not want to give any comments.
That's okay. Excellent. Thank you very much.
Thank you.
Thank you the next question comes from Spencer Horgan from Deutsche Bank. Please go ahead.

Yes, thank you good morning. And three things please and first one is actually first two are coming back to things you previously talked about, the first one is the separate account provisions in the Netherlands and was just wondering is there any sort of sensitivity you can give us on that going forward for various market movements?

And second point is coming back to you – you've just mentioned which is the Financial Markets bit, within the wholesale bank, which is obviously exceptionally strong in the first quarter. Could you give us a little bit more color on where that's coming from and in particular how we should think about that in the coming quarters?

And then the third thing is I just wanted to check, have you disclosed anywhere the split of the assets which you have reclassified from available for sale into the loans and receivables? And – because I like to keep track of the total asset exposure, and obviously just because they've been reclassified doesn't mean they're not still there. Thank you very much.

Okay. Well, let met first start with the Financial Markets, and to give some color there on what happened? I mean if you look at the Financial Market business overall, it's a very positive result. You could – and then you have to think like what is it, because I mean we had increased volatility – and the volatility in that sense helps in Financial Markets because there was increased activity. There is an structural component in that as well. And there is since there are – I mean there is less players in the market around these days, I mean we are getting more frequent calls to do business.

So what you see is overall, ballpark, we say like 70% of the results are more related to client related business, and 30% is just the good position taking, which has happened. So, and again, client related business has to do with Debt Capital Markets business, where we create a nice fee income. It has to do with derivative business. You get better bid/ask spreads as well. So overall, I think Financial Markets, I would say it's a 70/30 type of client profit attribution. So, we hope that there is a good component in there. Is that sort of guaranteed money in the back forever? No, because that depends on how loyal customers are in the long run.

If I look at the separate account provision, I think the difficulty with giving one fix set of sensitivities is that it doesn't work because that fluctuate. Because some of these elements they are -- sort of they have an implication on each other. Let me just give a simple example: I mean if interest rates are going down and equities at the same time are going down, that has a different effect than if interest rates are going up and equities are going down, because there are various amounts of guarantees written in this type of business. So, one set of metrics is not easy to give on a non-linear portfolio.

I think if you look at the reclassified assets, we gave that in the Q4 presentation, I think what we actually told there is that we have the ABS portfolio, it was 13 billion but there is also predominantly one part which is the corporate bonds which were reclassified as well. But we can come back with the precise breakdown but it was in the Q4 presentation.
Yes, I guess what I was wondering is if you could give the split of assets as we move forward through the coming quarters, but I guess it hasn't moved too much from the fourth quarter --

No. So, I think, overall, what you see is minus 0.7 billion in revals in Q1 on this portfolio. And again, just to be precise, it was the non-U.S. RMBS prime 8.7, the U.K. non-conforming 0.5 CMBS is one, and other ABS is 3, and corporate bonds 9.
Okay. Perfect. Thank you very much.
Thank you. The next question comes from the Thomas Nagtegaal from RBS. Please go ahead.

Good morning. I have got two questions, basically. First one on your non-performing loans and your coverage ratio. Non-performing loans increased about 36% in Q1. What do you expect for the remainder of the year, if the economic conditions do not improve? And are you comfortable with your coverage ratio of 29%, and do you expect it to stay at this level or do you have to increase it further down the cycle?

Secondly, on real estate, in the presentation, you show that you have 50.5 billion direct real estate exposure. 6.2 billion is not valued through to P&L but the amortized cost. In the past, you indicated that about 1.5 billion was in insurance portfolio. What is the remainder and how much impairments have you taken on this portfolio in the last three quarters? Thank you.

Okay. If we talk about the NPLs and the expectations, I think if you see the economy not deteriorating but staying precisely where it is right now, although it's hypothetical, then we still expect elevated risk cost to happen over this quarter or over this year. So, I mean we have elevated risk cost levels at 108 right now and we would expect that to continue.

And why is it the case? I mean it is not all asset classes giving you difficulties at the same time. And what we already mentioned before, you first expect that more in the leverage business or in some of the more real estate businesses. Also, we have a deterioration in the U.S. mortgage portfolio right now. And some of the other assets classes have just a more longer trailing effects. So, not all of these come at the same time. But more elevated levels like it is right now -- that is what we would expect if the economy doesn't change.

If you look at the coverage ratio at 29%, for me the coverage ratio doesn't tell too much because that just depends. I mean if we have mortgages which are non-performing, then you have a relatively high coverage. So, that means that you have a relatively high NPL because the mortgage is defaulting, but at the same time your coverage ratio or your collateral is higher. Therefore, you need less coverage. So, if you expect more delinquencies in your corporate portfolio unsecured today you need a higher coverage ratio, with mortgages you need less.

If I then talk about the real estate part, I recognize the 15.5 total real estate exposure. I also recognize the 6.2 which doesn't go via the P&L, but then, if we have the 9.3 billion left, basically, we have split it up between the bank and the insurance. The bank has four and the insurance has six. So, I don't know precisely where the one and a half comes from.

No, it was, I think, in the presentation of Q4 when you stated that you had a small portfolio amortized cost as well. But my question is more what's exactly left in the 6.2 billion which is not revalued through the P&L and how much impairments have you taken on the portfolio in the last three quarters?

If you look at the part which does not get revalued through the P&L, there is a part of it which is real estate development business and on the development we have taken some impairments and I think the total was 22? Yes, 22 million. Then there is a part which is our own buildings which are at cost, and as long as they are trading or trading valued at above this level, you don't need to impair it. And then there is a little bit of miscellaneous.
Okay. Thank you. A little bit of expansion on the coverage ratio question, have you already assumed a decline in collateral values going forward in your NPL provisioning assumptions?

Yeah. Because if you actually look at, for instance, your increased provisioning, for say, for example, Dutch mortgages, that is not driven so much by poor performance but is more because you index your house prices and therefore you're basically, your LGDs are moving up.
Okay. Thank you very much.
Thank you, the next question comes from Frank Stoffel from Merrill Lynch. Please go ahead.

Yes, good morning. It's Frank Stoffel from Merrill Lynch. Just three questions, please. I guess under Basel II, Basel II is quite punitive with regards to a downward migration of ABS securities. Of the remaining ABS that are sitting on your bank balance sheet, in the first quarter or in the second quarter, have you repackaged them or tried to move them to the insurance balance sheet on any kind – in any way changed the treatment of these to avoid the negative impact of the rating downward migration on your risk-weighted assets?
Second question: On your reclassified €13 billion of ABS, and by reclassifying them, have you avoided any impairments or cash losses on these investments in the first quarter?

And then lastly, in particular from the U.S., I'm hearing that the conditions you're offering at ING Direct in the U.S. are very aggressive and really at the top end of your peers – could you please comment on that? Thank you.

I think let me take the first two questions already on the ABSs and Basel II. If you look at the securitization rules, indeed they are particularly harsh on single B. Now where would that be – where would that first and foremost be of relevance? That was on the Alt-A portfolio and this was one of the driving forces to do the transaction with the state that we don't have this large migration risk anymore on our portfolio. So that has helped.

If you then look at the other ABS portfolios, I still need to remember that – and you can correct me if I am wrong, but still it is somewhere like 83% of the portfolio is rated at the ' triple A' level. So, this is something which is – you keep it on your radar screen as a concern, but if you ask me, like, is there something like, do I need to do a, sort of, a trade to immediately resolve that the answer is no, but certainly we would be looking at how can we, sort of, prevent this migration risk.

If you look at the second question, which is the reclassifications. Did reclassifications do anything on the impairments? I think that that is not the case because, well, first and foremost what we reclassified were assets where there was no reason to look at any impairments at all. And so impairments under AFS would have been zero on that and impairments reclassified is – it's a bit the same level. So in that sense: No, reclassification did not have an impact there on this portfolio.
So your cash losses and credit losses in the first quarter would have been identical if you hadn't reclassified the €13 billion of ABS?
You're saying it right. Yeah.
Okay. Thank you.
Okay, the third question I think we will ask Dick Harryvan, our leader of ING Direct to comment on. Dick?

In terms of our product conditions in the U.S., well, first of all, if I look at the saving side, the rate is now down to 1.5% which is very much middle of the pack and allowing us to maintain our savings and savings growth going forward. As far as the mortgages are concerned, we have really tightened up on the underwriting conditions, so the, our new mortgages the average loan to value is 60% and the average FICO score is 760, so it's extremely high credit worthiness of our clients, which does allow us to offer a competitive rate. We're not offering 30-year fixed mortgages. Only three, five and seven year ARMs. We have shied away and greatly reduced exposure, let's say in new business, from the most volatile states being California and Florida. So it's very much more in the heartland and East Coast that we are writing business at the moment. So, very high quality business at a competitive rate.

I am just a bit surprised about the €13 billion of net production, I guess as it's related to the U.S. and to Germany. I think this is significantly more than what you have shown over the last quarters, I believe? Is it just down to luck or good marketing? If you say the conditions you are offering were in the middle of the pack?

The 13 billion, our total mortgage production in the first – oh, savings, sorry. In savings, 11 billion was the production, of which approximately three in the U.S. and three in Germany. We have been aggressively reducing rates in – sorry, in the U.S. – and more recently also in Germany. So we will see an improvement in margin there going forward.

So all our countries produced positive savings inflows. We see since the beginning of the year actually that in many markets, not in the Dutch market, that savings competition has decreased somewhat, as far as the price setting is concerned, because the central banks are giving so much liquidity. So that's been good for us.
Okay. Okay, great. Thank you very much.
Thank you. The next question comes from Chris Hitchings from KBW. Please go ahead.

Hi, thanks very much. Indeed, Chris Hitchings, KBW. A number of issues: Can you explain a little bit more – you have re-priced and de-risked your Japanese variable annuity policies, for example, because of large DAC unlocking exposure on the old book. But if I remember correctly, you completely re-priced Japanese annuities about a year or 18 months ago. Are the problems arising on the new book or the old book? And if they're, as I suspect, on the old book, what's the point and purpose and effect of re-pricing anew? Could you give us some idea more of just what you are doing on, say, the U.S. annuities as well?

And could you also explain, so this is my second question, the value of new business? Clearly you were talking about these re-pricing of new products. Can you help us as to are there any other aspects in that change in new business? Are there any aspects of assumptions, economic assumption changes, which you've made?

And finally, could you give us some update – we've not mentioned recently at all how the notes from the Dutch state are ever going to be redeemed. Although you did mention, I think, at the Analyst Day, some views that others had seemed to have got better deals. Can you give us some update on thoughts as how that might happen, and whether you've had any draw-away from the Dutch government? Thank you.

Yeah, if we maybe start on the Japanese part, with the VA business, I think in the VA business on Japan, what we do have is both higher volatilities, lower interest rates, but we are basically exiting the Japanese SPVA business. So in that sense, what is there to say? I mean, in essence, we already did a lot of efforts in the past in reducing tracking error, in trying to get a more accounting symmetrical, but at the same time, yeah, we are taking right now a step further, as – well, that is not something we want to do.
And then maybe Tom can add something on the U.S. part on what we did there in changing our product offering.

Yes, Chris, on the current in-force product, we've done a lot on the LifePay Plus withdrawal benefit. We have reduced the rollup and this is on page 27 of Koos' presentation, we reduced the rollup. The maximum annual withdrawal – remember, depending on your age, you can take out 5%, 4% in the first withdrawal. We reduced all those by 1% across the board. We had a ratchet in many of the riders that ratchet every quarter. We've changed that to once a year for an annual ratchet. We have also reduced the commissions on the in force, and we have done more hedging, particularly hedging our new business, roll hedging our new business. So that's all on the in force.

We are now looking to launch a new set of products, which in the U.S. will only have index funds, so there'll be no basis for us, so it's easier to hedge. We will significantly reduce the value of the guarantee so substantially lower rollups if any. And less ratchets, maybe no ratchets as well. And then we will lower the commissions overall on the new products and pay them over – pay more of it over time versus up front. So that reduces the DAC build-up, and then obviously we will do more hedging of all four of the Greeks (1.01.23) on the new product.

Then just why don't I continue on the VNB, on new business, obviously the re-pricing on the variable annuity, if you look at the U.S. statistical supplement where we breakout the VNB and the IRR on the new business, you'll see a significant part of the decline in VNB was in variable annuity. I think it went from plus-21 or so in the first quarter last year to minus 13. And that's because, one, we're selling much less VA, so that increases the expense gap and has a dampening effect on the IRR and the VNB, and that's by design, because we are certainly looking to significantly reduce the amount of the old product that we sell (1.02.20) and eventually we'll put that in a closed block (1.02.23). And so the volume has an impact. And clearly, with significantly lower interest rates it has the effect of reducing the IRR and therefore the VNB. In fact, because we have negative VNB in the variable annuity business, our IRR is actually below our weighted average cost of capital.

So the big driver is -- in the U.S. on VNB -- is VA. Also we put our financial products business in runoff. We had done significant amounts of that (1.02.58) business in '06, '07 and the early part of '08. You know, the market's changed and we've decided to put that in runoff so therefore that also is a significant lowering impact on the VNB.
Okay. Thanks.

Your question related to the Dutch state, let me put it in perspective. There was a question raised at the annual meeting where someone mentioned that one of our competitors had a better deal on the core Tier-1, a better exit deal than we had. And the question was; can you get that as well? Well, of course, we would like always to get a better deal but we don't have a better deal from the government than we have currently at this point in time. With respect to planning to pay that off, of course if we could we would, but at this moment I don't think we are in a position to do so. But we're constantly evaluating opportunities when they present themselves but so far they haven't.
Thank you. The next question comes from Benoit Pétrarque from Kepler. Please, go ahead.

Good morning. Benoit Pétrarque from Kepler in Amsterdam. Okay. My first question was just on Europe and the commercial book which you don't disclose much about. Most of the banks in Europe have signaled that Q4 and Q1 saw a sharp deterioration in assets quality and I think you have shown that as well in your slide. Could you comment on the recent trends in the middle market and also the large cap segments by recent trend? I mean, what you've seen so far in April and May? Also relating to this question – what is your current exposure to leverage finance? I remember that ING has been a big player in leverage finance in the past so could you just remind us what is your total exposure?

And the second question is on the level – double leverage, can you give us an update where your regulator stands with regard to double leverage? And yeah, looking at your divestment program in the U.S., I will actually wonder whether you will get less diversification benefits from the bank insurance model going forward and whether it will make sense to decrease the leverage forecast.

And the last question is on the Alt-A. If I am right deal (1.05.24) commission approved the Alt-A transaction for the next six months. Is that reasonable to assume that you might have to pay the Alt-A on board if the cost of capital decreased to more reasonable levels going forward? Thank you very much.

Yeah. I think if you look at asset quality commercial book, I mean is there anything to be said between end of March and early April. Well, the first thing is I think on loans, I mean you look at the performance and covenant breaches of the more, the larger loans as and when they come but it's not that you have a sort of a statistic like on the retail side where you can follow delinquencies more on a monthly basis. So I don't think there is as compared to a quarter-end something meaningful to be said. I mean, you can see financial markets improving but real economy, I mean you cannot sort of spot a trend directly on that one.

If you look at leverage finance business, you indicated that we are a large player on the leverage finance side. In general what you could say is, we are actually a small player on the leverage finance side because that is a business where we basically stopped producing already early in – was it 2008? Yeah. Because we have a book and it's a total of 8 billion and if you look at the 8 billion, the biggest part of it is small tickets, and as small tickets we are talking about less than 50 million in each of them. So it's an overall portfolio and I think we have an overall provisioning on that specific part of somewhere in the order of 200 million but there is no growth in that portfolio.

And yes, you see in general, you see some deterioration and therefore you see the provisioning of debt part moving upwards. If you talk about double leverage, yes we have said like well we are a bank and an insurance company, and although many assets they go down together there is still one specific asset category or one risk category which is interest rates. I mean we simply benefit in the insurance company from interest rates going up and on the banking side those mechanics are differently. I mean an interest rate moving down has a good effect on us there, so there is an element of netting there for which we allow ourselves a diversification benefit.

If the difference in size between bank and an insurance company will change the composition in the group, then you would have to re-look at the diversification benefit, but for this moment, I don't see a reason to change that.
And then from a regulatory perspective, I mean, I guess you have some chat with your regulator on a monthly basis?

We have – always we have to apply to the financial conglomerate rules, so we have discussions with the regulators. And yes they look at your overall group capital and they compare that with minimum standards bank and insurance ignoring a double leverage. So and that is something which has always been tested and which has continued to be doing so.

With respect to the Alt-A transaction and the approval by the European commission, that's correct. They have asked for information which we have provided and are in the process of providing. So we are beginning discussions with them.
Okay. Thank you.
Thank you. The next question comes from Farooq Hanif from Morgan Stanley. Please go ahead.

Hi, good morning everybody. I have three questions actually. The first question is when you did your testing, the severe stress test scenario to get the 154 basis points. You explained that you took an average view over 2009, 2010 and divided it by two. Could you talk about what you really expect in terms of the shape of losses in '09 versus 2010 because clearly right now you are having U.S. mortgage type of pressures, but next year the longer tail like corporate losses could be bigger? Could you talk about the shape? That would be very interesting.

Second question is the new VA contracts that you talk about in the U.S., are they still essentially a WB product, but with far lower guarantees and lower commissions and just all the things that you described. But it's still a withdrawal benefit product, and are you happy with the notion of losing market share quite considerably? So would you be happy dropping out of top 10? That's question number two.

And number three very quickly, of the 11 billion of RWA going up because of ratings migration, obviously that was netted of by other things, but that 11 billion I mean what severity of ratings migration in pattern RWA growth, do you expect the Q3, Q4 in the rest of the year? Thank you.

Let me take the first question on the stress test. If you look at the stress test what we did indeed, its 154 or 158 on average. If you look at it what did they do over the years? I think there is a difference of 1 billion in terms of that year one '09 would be a bit lower and in year too you would have it a little bit higher. So but it's not precisely have half, I think the year too 2010 would be a billion higher. So there is a bit of open on equality in that part. Again Farooq, the only thing is I don't want to call this necessarily a stress test I want to say like it's just a scenario with a significant deterioration from where we were on 1 of Jan, and its just give you an indication of sensitivity. So it's not a stress test but it's also not my expectation, it's just simply a scenario with the deterioration from now than this number would come out, then may be.

Yes, may be on the risk weighted assets. Risk weighted assets driven by two things, one is, if you look at house prices going down hedges is the biggest driver on risk weighted assets on the mortgages side and it is rating migration which does it on the wholesale side. So really to see like what are the expectations you could say that the house price declines as they have we have witness right now. They are part of the risk weighted asset migration on the mortgages side. So that is actualized and if it spokes, then of course it doesn't increase. But if house prices deteriorate further than we suffer.

If you look at the wholesale lending side that is more PD migration so in other words default migration and as you know how to process in a bank work if you review your wholesale loans you know through out the year, so you do expect that when you review all of these loans that there will be a migration of the PD. So you do expect that to go up a little bit. And then you have the wildcard which is a bit more the ABSs and on the ABSs, you have a limited effects, but that only starts to deteriorate if it moves below that BBB level and especially when it gets to B, and as you know we have a relatively high rated portfolio. So you don't have immediate expectations there over migration, but that is more, over a long-term debt that could be an issue depending on how the economy face.
Could I just ask before you answer the last question on VAs. Can I just ask what is the amount of ABS and corporate bond that you have rated A? And BBB right now?
May be, Tom, you will answer the VA question.

Yes Farooq, I think that when yes – you look forward at the VA market. I think that there are going to be two strategies. And I think we expect to be at the forefront of competing on lower costs lower guarantee benefits and then lower risks for cost for us. And so I think the net effect will be a significant reduction in the ongoing annual fees that we charge to consumers, versus the other players who today compete with a higher benefit although they're reducing those benefits and they charge 350 basis points or more.

So I think our products will be much lower in costs, but they do provide a lower guarantee. I actually think that depending on what consumers think the lower fees over time on a index fund may prove to be as good as competitive. So I think it's to be seen how the competition plays out, we certainly don't believe we're going to fall out over time and we'll take a while for the markets to adjust to the new basis of competition, but we would expect to be a top player.

More importantly though beyond just the new products what we've said is we are going to focus our annuity business on the rollover market. There are 76 million baby boomers in the U.S. that are 45 to 63. So there is enormous opportunity in the rollover and we think a low cost easy-to-understand simple annuity to rollover balances will be quite attractive. We have a significant advantage in the rollover market because we are a top three player in the U.S. in retirement services and we're the leading insurance company other than maybe TIAA-CREF, but other top players are Fidelity and Vanguard. We have $10 billion of assets rolling over per year on existing so we would be looking to sale these de-risk rollover annuities to that 10 billion.

Right now on the ING, well I'll call ING legacy so excluding CitiStreet we had about 3 billion in a year rolling over, we are getting about 30% of that rollover on CitiStreet obviously we up until now we have gotten zero of the rollover but there is about 7 billion of that total 10 is from CitiStreet. So, if overtime we can approach the 30% there, I think you are looking at a significant opportunity, and I think we'll be able to have a significant share because of the rollover opportunity. In addition, we will also sell the new annuity products in the general market.
If you just forgive my ignorance, I mean what do you mean by simple rollover product? Is that an immediate payout annuity?

No, basically it's – what we are talking about would be – we will have a SPIA or an immediate annuity and fixed annuities and fixed index annuities, but on the VA part of that and we think given the amount of time people live in retirement these days in the U.S., that many will still want a VA, and so the VA will be that lower-risk VA that I have talked about going forward.
Okay. Thank you. And do you have an answer on the about AAA and BBB?
If we go to the ABS rating breakdown of the Group, then its 83% is AAA, 9% is AA and 3% is A. So, that is the sort of the highest rating.
Okay. Thank you very much.
Thank you. The next question comes from Nick Holmes from Nomura. Please go ahead.

Yes, hello, I have three questions. First one is just going back to the NPL coverage ratio. Just wanted to ask whether the fall to 29% from 42% a year ago, which is pretty big, is really all due to business mix changes like more mortgages as Koos mentioned, or whether there's anything else that you think is important for us to know about?

Second question is looking at the DAC unlocking, just wondered if you could tell us how much could be written back if markets improve. Indeed perhaps you can give us some sort of feel for how much could already have been written back in Q2.
And then third question is just could you give us an update on your thinking about whether you'll pay an interim dividend. Thanks.

Okay. Nick, on the NPL side, indeed, I gave as effect our business mix, which plays a big role, because in general. Let's look at two things. One is if we look at lending, then we lend to lower-rated institutions or individuals based on good collateral and you do it more unsecured on higher rated. And that rule has not changed. So, that's one. So, that means if we look at provisioning really if you have a lot more mortgages where you could say an individual is lower rated but you have higher collateral, mortgage production is the biggest driver of an NPL coverage ratio.

Did we change and so that coverage ratio is not lower because of a change in the way how we make our reservations or the way how we make our loan loss provisioning. And I mean you cannot compare the one crisis with the other. Overall, we have always been relatively conservative in loan loss provisioning within the accounting guidelines which were given. Hence, the releases we had in the past. Now I cannot say that that will happen in the future. The only thing I want to illustrate is that my coverage ratio is not lower because we changed the policy, because we still do our provisioning exactly the way we did it before.
Okay. Thank you.

Yes, Nick, on the DAC unlocking, that's obviously a complicated question but let me give you sort of a shorthand version and there are some complexities around this because you have to keep in mind that we have 650,000 or so VA contracts outstanding and therefore how that all fits together is not sort of just a mean average. But as you know, Koos has showed on pages 24 and 25 the negative DAC unlocking comes from three sources. One is the equity fee income so that given how far the markets have dropped, we project, as you know, wherever the quarter ended. So, at the end of the first quarter, the SMP was at 798 and we assume from that number that 2.25% quarterly increase.

Therefore, we have equity fee unlocking as you know because we are now assuming growth off that much lower number. In the past, we had not had guaranteed benefit unlocking because the contracts had not gone so much in the money, but just like for fee income, that's more fees on assets under management, but on the guaranteed benefit cost, as the markets go down, again, we never assume a mean reversion, so we are now assuming in the first quarter that the equity market over the long run will grow from 798 at 2.25%, and so what you're finding on the guaranteed benefits is somewhere out there in 20 years, we actually will pay some of those. And so that's, and as the market goes down more, and more payments would be due, well out, we do the – we amortize the DAC according to that.

And then the third area is we assume a set basis points of impairments in our long-term assumptions, obviously, we have had more impairments in the third and fourth quarter. So the actual on the projected have also resulted in some DAC unlocking. Clearly if any of those – so if the equity markets grows more overtime from the 798, more than 2.25% per quarter than we'll have the opposite effect and we will have the DAC unlocking on the upside and the same would be the case in the guaranteed benefits, that you, over time, you might assume that what you pay 20 to 30 years now will be much less if the markets go – grow faster than the 225.

And the same with impairments, if impairments improve. So yeah I think that you should assume again, simplistically, that there will be positives. There are two additional complications that you have to be aware of. One is that we have – as Koos said, we have increased the equity hedging on the VA block to protect statutory capital. And therefore, whatever benefit we have in the rising markets and DAC – it might be offset to some degree by the short futures position and the put options that we have in place. And then, you recall Nick, because you've been around for a while that up until the third quarter of 2002, we actually used mean reversion. And we suspended that in the third quarter of 2002. A few times over the last five years, we looked at going back to mean reversion but for variety of reasons we didn't do that. But we are getting to a point where one could argue that the best estimate of 798 plus 2.25% is probably – maybe too conservative. So we are looking at mean reversion and should we reconsider that. We haven't made any decisions. We'll look at that in the future.

But to the extent that we did put mean reversion and that would clearly have a cap on the up side. So that would also impact the future of benefits from DAC unlocking. But, it is a mirror image and also the last point I make is you could only unlock the DAC once, so once you have amortized it, it's gone unless you have significant upside activity down the road.

Tom, thank you for that very full answer. I'm just coming back to the annuity guaranteed benefit costs. I'm, I suppose slightly surprised at the size of the charge in Q1. And is that – does that reflect a change in methodology?

No. I think, well, look when we did. So the first time we really had a material guaranteed benefit unlock was in the fourth quarter. So what we assume and we did that unlocking as I think the S&P ended at 903 at 12.31 '08. So we use 903 growing at 2.25% for the future, and that resulted in the 346 million unlocking.

But then say, we actually – so as part of that assumption that the 903 should have grown to about 916 or so in the first quarter, it didn't and went to down to 798. So now everything goes down 105 points on the S&P and in the future from 798 we assumed the 2.25%.

So, we're assuming that the money position is more in the money because we're – forever we've locked in that 105 point decline from 903 to 798. So as a result of that when you look at the value of all those guaranteed benefit costs, since they – each year in effect have a lower assumption on where the equity markets are, we therefore had to do unlocking again in the first quarter. And there is -- the further you go down, more and more contracts get in the money. So it does have a significant negative effect. Again that could in the future depending on markets reverse as quickly as we've written it down, it might go the other way depending on a lot of different assumptions.

And then the final thing is in those future guaranteed benefits, in the third quarter I think the swap rate was closer to 4% and now it's – I think in the first quarter it was less than three, so that also means the present value of the guaranteed benefit and larger that also had an impact on the DAC unlocking.
Okay. Thank you very much. Sorry, just one very quick follow-up question which is on the hedging, has anything changed there of those products?

We have done more hedging, so the notional amount of the hedge has gone from around 2 million to 5. But we did that not so much just to protect the fee income and the guaranteed benefits, that was really more of a – to protect statutory capital so that we don't have to put more capital into the U.S. so that's a change.

In addition, Koos and I and others are looking at instead of hedging by short futures to protect statutory capital to go to put spread and collars and so it's, we did a billion of that in the first quarter switching from short futures to put spreads option and we'll probably do more of those going forward.
Okay. Thank you very much for that. May be sorry, but just a last question on the dividend?
Yeah the last question on the dividend, Nick. That's not at this moment on our agenda. We will take a look at that later in the year when we have a better sight of where our numbers are.
Okay. Thank you very much.
Thank you. The next question comes from Tony Silverman from Standard & Poor's Equity Research. Please go ahead.

Yes, thank you, I'd just like to come back to the helpful slide 16, which has the bank profits before market impacts. And the narrative then moves on really to talk about the underlying profits which obviously includes reference to market impacts, but it would be helpful if you could talk about how particularly retail banking moved at the level before market impacts, because it seems it might have been flat or up (1.28.26).

And second question was if you could just clarify on the conglomerate solvency, which you've mentioned that you are subject to, how that has moved as a coverage ratio in Q1? And yeah, that's it. I think the question on VA's has been answered.

Maybe quickly on the retail side, I mean, well firstly if we go to page 16 then indeed you see an underlying result and then you get a whole series of impairments. If you actually look at our retail banking business overall, if you look at the commercial results there, before – the first thing is on the retail side I don't own a lot of security. So that means like impairments on pressurized assets they play hardly any role there. I think on the retail side the only thing what plays a role there is my loan loss provisioning part and my risk cost. And if you look at the risk cost overall on the retail side they were at 330 million over the quarter. So that is basically the biggest driver there.

And then of course the other part, which play a big role is – the drastic cost reduction, which we have done. But the part – the topline of the retail was more driven by the fact that initially we had stiff competition there on the savings money and we are adjusting those rates down gradually right now. So, that's in a nutshell the retail part.

The precise question on the conglomerates and solvency, because you are talking about a coverage ratio. If I look at the coverage ratio for conglomerates, I mean, yes we do have a holding company and in a holding company you have leverage. Nevertheless, there is a sort of a test, that is the Financial Conglomerates Act, and that Financial Conglomerates Act just looks at the total amount of equity what you have and then it looks at how much is it covered. So that is one of the tests which is more from a regulatory perspective. If we look at it more from a market perspective, yes, then you more look at, do you have enough capital to cover for your internal risks? And that is our internal way of looking at it and both of them are adequate.
And do you have a number for that regulatory -

No. I don't have it right now here, but I think it is something that you'll have to then look at minimum required consolidated E.U. and at the same time you look at your bank minimum requirements and you relate that to total equity. And I would be, for the precise details of that, I mean, I would get in contact with capital management on that, but that is not something which is causing a concern for us.
Thank you.
Thank you. The next question comes from Farquhar Murray from FPK. Please go ahead.

Hi, there. I am Farquhar Murray from Fox-Pitt. Just three questions if I may. And just starting with the kind of commercial result of 2.2 billion, it's clear that's a substantial recovery from where it was in the fourth quarter. I just wondered if could just run through the sustainability of that and most particularly, obviously, on the financial markets business I'd particularly like to know how that's continued in the second quarter and where you see it going longer term?

Second question, if I may, on the other DAC component. I'm just wondering, I mean, clearly the equity market's pretty much back where it started at the start of the year, how much of that number could we see recover in the second quarter?

And then finally, just on rating migration: The 11 billion of risk-weighted asset growth was about 3% growth in the quarter and the IMS kind of discussed the rule of thumb for pro-cyclicality under Basel II over eight to 10%. You're slightly north of that but not very much. I just wonder whether that would be a useful rule of thumb for the next couple of quarters going forward? That's it. Thanks.

Maybe let me start with the financial markets parts. Again, yes, we had outstanding results there and we split that business up. You have ALM results; you have prop results and you have client-related results. All of them were actually pretty good but at the same time you could say that 70% of the attribution is more to client-related. And that's both if you look at simple things like debt capital market business that's where we were not a player and now we are. So, we are collecting the benefits from this business right now and that is simply because there are less players in the market left at this moment.

So, in that sense there is a more structural element in there which we expect to continue. Do you expect to continue that forever? The answer is potentially not because, I mean, there will be competition again as – if markets start to improve. But this is not all, sort of, proposition taking what is in that business. So, in that sense relatively hopeful. Forward-looking, we don't make statements on that part. Other points?
Just how has the second quarter developed so far in terms of activity levels from clients?
Yeah, I think on the activity levels of clients, I think that is something we will comment on the next quarter.
Okay.

There was another point on the risk-weighted assets, on the migration. In general, if you look at it what I already alluded to is the mortgage is more driven by house prices and migration is something ahead which plays a role for more the corporates, but overall that E.U. rule is not a very strange rule. I mean, we look at it in terms of projections as well. The only thing what we have is, we do have some levers to, sort of, cut it down. One of the things is a little bit more balance sheet integration. Because remember we were a relatively large bank in terms of owning investments and if you let your investments, so your bond portfolio, run off that serves a bit as a cushion as well. So I recognize if you leave everything alone you are rating migration number, but at the same time we do have some countervailing effects. Not as beneficial as what we had in the first quarter with the old A, I mean that was of course a big help there, but overall in terms of balance sheet integration we have a lever in our hands.
Okay.
