Yeah on the – Farquhar, on the other DAC unlocking, again with the caveat that it's complicated analysis and it – we actually have – do this on 650,000 contracts so I am giving you a rough rule of thumb, so it's a rough rule of thumb. If the equity markets move 10%, that would have up or down in the rough range of euro 150 to 200 million on equities, so keep in mind each quarter we expect up 2.25 and so from – if it's 10% above that or below then it would have that range that I just talked about.

In addition, you have to look at what's going on with interest rates and so 100 basis point move in interest rates again would be about €50 million. And that may change as rates go significant – up or down beyond the 100 basis points. And also remember what I said that we do have a 5 billion hedge-to-hedge capital, we're really not – we don't have this position because of IFRS hedging. And 4 billion of that is a short future position on the S&P 500 and 1 billion of that as a put spread collar again on the S&P 500. So that – if markets go up, it would have an opposite effect obviously on that hedge. And then finally, as I said before, we are considering going back to mean reversion. So if we don't then you don't have to worry about it but if we do and depending on which quarter, yeah, mean reversion is just that you assume things move back to the mean over time, say for, like, we look at three years back, five years forward, for example, would be pretty typical. And so as markets move up, if you have mean reversion on, depending on your corridor, you will actually cap the movement of the market up so at some point it cuts off the benefit. So, again, not saying we're going to do it or not but that's another factor to consider.
Thanks. Just a point of detail on that 150 to 200 million: Is that just the other DAC kind of guarantee benefit component or are you adding in the fee-related hedging?

No, that's the guaranteed benefit unlocking. I think we've all – we've told you in the past that on the fee unlocking for every 1% -- since I gave you 10%, let me just -- for 10% it would be 100 to 130 million.
Okay. So, that's then on top of that 150 to 200?
Yes, there is really – as long as the contracts are in the money, there is in addition to the equity fee-related that you're used to, you have the benefit unlocking.
Yes, but as a rule of thumb, we'd expect it to be just symmetric to up and down?

It's symmetric but I'd have to get into all the deltas because at some point the gamble probably means that it changes, but from where we are today up to a certain up or down, I think it's right. If you go well beyond that up or down, it probably would end up being a different rule of thumb. But – so, that would be my answer.
Great. Thanks.
The next question comes from Bruno Paulson from Bernstein. Please go ahead.

Thank you very much. Firstly, on the margins in the bank: With ING Direct we assume a 60 million or so headwind next quarter because of the full effect of the deal with the Dutch Government and Alt-A coming through. And secondly, are there signs of Dutch retail margins improving or is that still as tough as ever?
Second question is, what's your economic capital position or, as you've told us what it is, where is it in the disclosure?

And finally a request: In the last few quarters you've given the commercial result and then the market effects and so on by business unit, not just the bank and insurance. That's actually quite helpful for modeling things out. I'm wondering if you could provide that again?
Dick, you want to do the ING?

Bruno, on the Dutch Government deal and the impact on income: So we had two of the three months already in the first quarter. So, it'll be a third more. Its impact is just over 100 million per quarter. So, it would be more like 30 million. I think that kind of pales by, let's say, the impact, let's say, of rate decreases on our savings products. So, let's say without giving a forward-looking statement, it's not necessarily, I mean, a reduction in interest income.
Yes, that's helpful.

Okay, that's the retail business in the Netherlands. We see our margins slowly getting a bit better and we anticipate that they – the movement will be a little bit more pronounced in the second half than in the first quarter. Economic capital, Koos?

Yes, Bruno, on the economic capital: Indeed we did not disclose this quarter our AFR to EC ratio for a number of reasons but the reason was not the deterioration because actually that AFR/EC ratio improved to 135%. So, it's up, so that means, like, it's better. The only reason why we didn't do it is we found actually two things of objection. The one is EC is of course quite sensitive to the credit spread especially on the insurance side because it's a very long-term business and you apply an illiquidity spread to policies and that is something which is a big factor in there.

Second part is yes, we are in this sense a little bit standalone that nobody else is doing this. So, the number is volatile although it has improved. There is an element of subjectivity with this one component which is illiquidity spread which made us realize, like, probably it's better to show this more on a once-a-year basis than to monitor this on a quarter-by-quarter basis. But now you have it anyway.
Thank you.
And you like to see us helping you with the commercial results, we'll take a look at that and see whether we can help you with that one.
Thank you.
Thank you. The next question comes from Ryan Palacek from Kempen. Please go ahead.

Yes. Good morning. Just a couple of detailed questions: First of all, after the reclassification of the asset backed securities that we saw in Q1, I'm wondering is it thinkable to see any further deconsolidation of the ABS portfolio or any other further steps to distance it from impacts of valuation impacts, but also potentially from ratings migration impacts?
And second question is what do you have for contingencies in the case that the Alt-A deal would not be approved by the European Union?
And finally on the AFR/EC question: The 130% – was that Group or was that for insurance? Can you give us some idea as to how that's been moving in insurance in the last quarter? Thanks.

Let me maybe first talk about reclassifications. Yes, we did reclassify part of the ABS portfolio and then, you could say, like, are there further steps there or are we envisaging further steps? Well, one of the things what we are doing right now is the following: Reclassifications – the primarily impact it has is on revaluation reserve because you start to stabilize that. What you see right now is although asset markets are a bit more quite, a bit more friendly at this moment, that plays one role. Second is we have seen changes in U.S. GAAP but they effected more the way how you impair. So there reclassifications don't play too much of a roll because reclassifications is a revaluation game.

But we are also looking a bit carefully of are they are going to be changes on the IFRS accounting standards as well. So that is why – I mean, I would not exclude further revalue – reclassifications but at the same time, for now, we are short of a holding our power a little bit dry. That is one.

If I look at the other part and that is rating migration – are we doing anything about this, because indeed reclassifications don't help you with rating migration. Rating migration is a thing on its own whether you classify it as this or that. Now on rating migration there are a few things what could help sell, buying protection, trying to buy securitized protection. We would be looking at things but that is more a process which we will – which we are looking at over the year, because again I gave you the rating distribution, the portfolio is relatively high rated right now. So I don't want to exclude that at the certain moment, something could be downgraded, but its not that all these – so these ABSs are about to become single B at this movement. So over time we are looking at solutions for this but it is not something where we are a making a priority that it has to be done before a certain date.

If I look at contingencies for Alt-A, I mean, we have a discretion with the EC and the EC they have said that the transaction in itself, the exchange for the Alt-A for funding for the state, that component of the transaction has been fully validated. They are still looking at it and of course, I mean, it's a highly complex transaction and they want to screen the pricing. They have said like well, potentially we want to be able to look at modifications but not on on the core of the transaction itself. So I don't think it's a bit – something where we need to make anticipations for right now. If I look at AFR/EC the number which I gave you, the 135, is a Group number and that is – oh, that's the insu – sorry, it's the insurance number and on the Group it's a 154. So now you have it all.
Okay. Thank you.
. There is a follow-up question from Farooq Hanif from Morgan Stanley. Please go ahead.

Hi, there. I just wanted to ask about your RBC ratio in the U.S. Kind of, overall what was it, if you can remind us, in 2008 and what have you done so far in the first quarter to have to put capital into the U.S. to keep that ratio up?

Yeah. Farooq, the RBC ratio, we are working on that in the first quarter because the Alt-A deal with the government right now it's, you probably don't know what Line nine is but it's basically we are holding more capital than we think we need given that it's a AAA credit. And so if we get the right treatment on that we'd be at about 313 as of March 31. So we try to keep it at 325, so we are working on some reinsurance and other deals to get it there. We did put capital in to the U.S. Part of it came from the holding company in the U.S. and part from the Group INGV of – we put €900 million in as part of that rating.
I'm sorry, if we put in the full impact of Line nine what would the RBC ratio be?
If we get the credit, it's 313, without the credit, I think it's 286.
Okay. Thank you very much.
. Thank you, sir. There appear to be no further questions. Please continue with any other points you wish to raise.
Okay. Then I would like to thank everybody for being on the call. And probably we'll see each other in the very near future in one of these occasions. So thanks very much, and good luck.
This concludes ING's first quarter 2009 conference call. Thank you for participating, you may now disconnect.
